awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Foundations of Quantum State Learning and Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to advance our scientific understanding of how to most efficiently learn or test the state of a quantum particle system.  Whenever researchers/engineers build a quantum device -- say, for a quantum teleportation experiment, or as a component of a quantum computer -- they need to check whether it works as intended.  That is, they need to be able to determine the quantum state of the particles it produces.  Given enough samples from the device, it is possible to determine the quantum state to any desired accuracy.  But due to the expensive nature of quantum experiments, it is important to seek highly efficient strategies for estimating the unknown state, ones that use as few samples as possible.  The overarching goal of the project is to try to mathematically determine the optimal samples vs. accuracy tradeoff for problems such as: a) learning an unknown quantum state; b) testing whether an unknown state is equal to a desired target state, etc.  Success in the project will tell us the efficiency benchmark against which all practical state-learning methodologies can be judged.  Additionally, the project contains a significant educational component involving undergraduate and graduate students in the research effort, and the insights gained will also filter into a free online quantum computing course curriculum.


At a more technical level, the project seeks to understand the optimal sample complexity of many basic problems in quantum state tomography and estimation.  Proposed problems include: a)  estimating a d-dimensional state's eigenvalues using o(d^2) samples; b) quantum tomography and state certification with respect to more stringent measures of accuracy, such as chi-squared divergence; c) testing whether a d x d quantum state is separable (unentangled) or far from separable using o(d^4) samples; d) performing 'm-measurement shadow tomography' with a number of samples linear in log(m) and polylogarithmic in the dimension; and e) improving the computational efficiency of known sample-optimal algorithms. For many of these problems, the investigator plans to use and extend the representation theory-based quantum learning framework developed recently with other researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award led to over a dozen scientific publications, as well as to the training and development of several undergraduate, master's, and PhD students at Carnegie Mellon University.

In research, significant progress was made on: developing new quantum algorithms for classical learning and estimation problems; developing new quantum algorithms for learning and statistical analysis of quantum data and quantum systems; and, developing new methods of protecting quantum computers from noise through error-correcting codes.  Particular highlights of the sponsored research works included the following:

  • A new approach to designing quantum error-correcting codes based on "fiber bundles", which gave the first major improvement to the efficiency of these codes in over a decade.
  • A new quantum algorithm for Monte Carlo estimation of a random quantity.  This algorithm generalizes "Grover's Algorithm" and all related "square-root speedups" for estimation problems.
  • An extremely simple proof of the "quantum union bound", a fundamental theoretical tool in quantum learning and quantum communication.
  • The most efficient known method for "shadow tomography" -- this is the task of estimating a large number of "observable values" of a quantum system from limited data.
  • New efficient algorithms for the quantum version of statistical hypothesis testing.
  • A new, optimally efficient algorithm for estimating a unitary quantum transformation.
  • A new, highly efficient method for estimating the "Pauli coefficients" of an unknown quantum noise model, one that does not require any quantum entanglement.
  • The most efficient known algorithm "state tomography" -- that is, learning all the parameters of an unknown quantum state.

In addition to these reseach highlights, the award supported the research and training of 4 PhD students at Carnegie Mellon University, as well as several undergraduate and master's students.  The PI broadly disseminated the research supported by this award, giving several public talks about it, making a dozen YouTube videos on the research and on related educational material, and incorporating ideas from the research into a new undergraduate course on quantum computing at Carnegie Mellon.
